Several reports by the Washington, D.C.-based non-profit called Social Compact, find that businesses could reap billions of dollars by catering to untapped urban markets.
John Talmage is the director of Social Compact, and he joins us now from Washington, D.C.
Thanks for joining us.
Thank you.
Your organization did a series of reports called drilldowns, and these were done in places like Miami, Los Angeles, Cincinnati.
What did you find there?

What we find in the cities that we conduct our research in is that there always are more people, more income, more aggregated income in these neighborhoods that people traditionally don't believe there are existing market conditions in.
How much extra income do these neighborhoods have, and what are they being spent on right now?
It varies from city to city.
I mean, in Detroit we found a billion dollars that was being spent outside the city from residents in these neighborhoods.
In Miami, we had extraordinary numbers.
In the area that we studied we found a 42 percent higher population, but in African-American neighborhoods we found a 90 percent higher population than the census had documented.
Those make census numbers meaningless in places like Liberty City, Little Haiti or the east side of Detroit.
And how exactly did you come upon these numbers that seem to be quite different from those found in the census?
Well it's not a sexy thing to do, but we're data miners.
(Soundbite of laughter)
So, we go through, we develop our own parcel level database.
You can imagine that the tax assessor for everybody who lives, or owns property, does not necessarily know anything about the characteristics of the household.
The utility company may know something about the characteristics of the household, because of how much water or electricity they consume; it doesn't care who owns the property.

By the time you merge these databases, 30 to 50 databases, building permit data, DMV data, credit bureaus data, you can begin to pick up missed units that ordinarily would not be captured in traditional market analysis.
If we could break this down a bit.
If you look at it, it seems like, well, these people have all this extra income, why wouldn't they just move to a better neighborhood?
What exactly is their financial situation?
Well, in many cases, one of things we pride ourselves on is our ability to measure the informal economic income.
It's not the illicit income, maybe that second job they have, the tips they may earn as a waitress, or the money they earn in babysitting.
So, in places like Los Angeles, where we just finished our most recent drilldown, we found that 10 percent of the income was in the informal economy.
That's what the difference is between living a marginal existence or having discretionary money to spend, which often is the case.
So, what kinds of businesses could really have an opportunity in these kinds of neighborhoods?
Well, I would start with, you know, we consider financial services and grocery, food access, to be fundamental building blocks for the ongoing development.
People have to eat.
They have to have a place to be able to deposit their money and what not.
And there's an emerging public policy imperative that says that these businesses need to be there.

If you look at some of the emerging research on the correlation between obesity and diabetes versus the lack of access to full service grocery, or research on the essence of crime, and the saturation of pawnshops or payday lenders, so these are bank branches, grocery stores, these are the types of businesses that can thrive in the inner city, once they have the information to know how to get there.

It seems like a lot of people, instead of spending money at these businesses because there's not, let's say, a grocery store in the neighborhood, they spend the money on bus fare to get to where they need to go.
As gas prices get higher, do you think more businesses will actually open up in some of these neighborhoods?
I think that's absolutely the case.
I mean, the two things that we are very confident on, where we founded our principles off from, is that the lack of information creates investment adversity.
You don't invest in things that you don't know about.
And so, as the cost of living increases, people will need to be able to go outside and be able to get their milk.
It's not a matter of convenience; it's a matter of necessity.
Wayne State conducted a study in Detroit, and they found that, of African-American families in the lowest third of income class, that most - that 35 percent didn't have access to cars.
So, if you don't have a grocery store in your neighborhood you're almost condemned to poor public health outcomes.
What about the issue of security?
Many of these neighborhoods do have higher rates of crime.
Isn't that a concern for a business owner?
Well, crime rates have been coming down.
But the perception of crime tends to outpace the actual numbers.

And, so, you may hear about a sensationalized murder, or some sort of trend that may be occurring, but when you look at the actual numbers and where they're occurring, it doesn't tend to be in the places where you might put a grocery store.
So, what we try to do with our information is to counter misperceptions of neighborhoods.
East Oakland, for example, the perception of crime is so high, but it's really - the crime rate is lower than the city of Oakland as a whole, and so are most parts of San Francisco.
So you've been mining all this data, and it all sounds very good on paper.
What can you actually do to get business owners to invest in these regions?
Because of our partnerships we have, we're able to put the information in the hands of folks who are able to, you know, attract a grocery store.
Columbia Heights in Washington D.C.
is an example, where Mayor Williams spent two years using our data to attract DC USA, which now has a target of Best Buy.
There are multiple branches of Washington Mutual that were opened up using this data in Houston.
So we're able to work with the development community, in order to try to massage the information in ways that they find useful, that leads to investment.
John Talmage is the director of Social Compact, an organization that's been looking at the untapped potential of some of America's poorest neighborhoods.
Thank you.
Thank you very much.
